awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Design of a Nanosat Constellation for Measuring Internal Gravity Wave Fluxes in the Earth's Stratosphere
awd_abstract_narration:
Gravity waves, meaning waves for which buoyancy provides the restoring force, are commonly seen propagating across the surfaces of ponds and lakes, in the wakes of ships, and breaking in the surf zone at the beach. Similar waves occur in the atmosphere, but atmospheric gravity waves can propagate vertically as well as horizontally.  Vertical propagation means that activity near the surface, such as winds blowing over mountains or updrafts in convective clouds, can influence the circulation at stratospheric levels.  Stratospheric circulation can in turn affect surface weather over much of the globe, and is a potential source of long-range forecast skill. Thus the driving of the stratosphere by gravity waves is a topic of both practical and scientific interest.

The goal of this project is to design a satellite constellation for observing atmospheric gravity waves. The constellation consists of nine low-cost cubesats using radio occultation (RO) to detect gravity waves in temperature profiles extending through the upper troposphere and lower stratosphere. RO is a technique which measures the refraction of signals from satellites of the Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS, which includes the GPS satellites) as they pass through the atmosphere.  At the levels of interest refraction can be used to deduce atmospheric temperature, thus the constellation would produce nine simultaneous temperature profiles, each containing wiggles indicating the presence of gravity waves.  These could be combined to determine the three-dimensional structure of a wave packet, from which its propagation and likely influence on stratospheric circulation could be inferred. 

The project is a feasibility study in which the PIs use a high-resolution atmospheric model, the Model for Prediction Across Scales (MPAS, in a global nonhydrostatic configuration), to generate realistic vertically propagating gravity waves. A virtual constellation "orbits" over the model simulation to determine what observations would be produced by the satellites for a given wave field and a given set of satellite, orbit, and instrument characteristics.

The work has societal relevance due to the desirability of better gravity wave representations in models used for weather prediction and to provide guidance to decision makers. In addition, the work contributes to the development of cubesat technology, which has a variety of commercial and scientific applications. Cubesats also provide valuable educational experiences, as they can be built and operated by university students. The project provides support and training to a graduate student, thereby promoting workforce development in this research area.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
There are a variety of ways of sounding the Earth’s atmosphere from space, but one technique in particular – radio occultation – is especially peculiar because it can be measure temperature and pressure in the upper atmosphere with a vertical resolution approaching that of radiosondes. Radio occultation works with two satellites: one satellite transmitting a radio frequency or microwave signal that is timed using extremely precise atomic clocks, and the second satellite receiving the signal after it passes horizontally through the limb of the Earth’s atmosphere. The vertical resolution, about 100 meters, is extraordinary for remote sensing and is ideally suited to measuring small-scale gravity waves from space. A single RO sounding cannot discern the horizontal wavefronts of gravity waves, but if we had a cluster of proximate RO soundings, we would be able to infer the vertical flux of horizontal momentum transported by the waves into the stratosphere, which is a key goal in atmospheric science. These waves are thought to contribute large amounts of unaccounted for momentum to well-known atmospheric phenomena. In our project, we set out a concept for an RO mission in which all Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSSs) are tracked by a close-formation constellation of RO satellites and performed two trade studies central to the design of such a mission.

In the first trade study, we sought out orbital configurations for close-formation constellations of RO satellites that would yield high quality clusters of RO soundings on the ground without requiring inordinate amounts of propulsion on-board the RO satellites. If not careful, a constellation of RO satellites would yield clusters of RO soundings on the ground that are closely spaced in the horizontal and in time but would fall along a straight line in the horizontal; such clusters cannot be used to infer horizontal wavelengths, which is necessary to determining the momentum flux carried by internal gravity waves. We looked into two possible configurations: mutual orbit groups, wherein RO satellites appear to orbit each other, and RAAN-spread constellations, in which RO satellites all have the same orbital inclination but slightly different right ascension of ascending node (RAAN). We found that the mutual orbit group constellation regularly and systematically produced high quality clusters of RO soundings spread out in two horizontal dimensions but required large amounts of propulsion in order to counter natural gravitational forces that act to disperse the constellation. No currently available propulsion system is available, and so mutual orbit group constellations were found not to be viable. We then found that the RAAN-spread constellation also produced high quality clusters of RO soundings at low latitudes but not as regularly as mutual orbit groups at high latitudes. Because RAAN-spread constellations require only small amounts of propulsion and because most of the interesting gravity waves science lies in low latitudes, we concluded that a mission to perform tomography on internal gravity waves by RO should use a RAAN-spread constellation of RO satellites.

In the second trade study, we sought to perform of simulation-retrieval demonstration of inferring internal gravity wave momentum flux using clusters of RO soundings that would be obtained by a RAAN-spread constellation. We did this by simulating an atmospheric with a semi-realistic spectrum of internal gravity waves as generated by deep tropical convection using a cutting edge model that can permit the generation of deep convection by the equations of motion in a certain region, which we set as the tropical western Pacific ocean. Such non-hydrostatic models are difficult to manage, but we were able to obtain 23 hours of model output with qualitatively realistic convection that emitted internal gravity waves. We adapted a wave optics model for simulating RO soundings that accounts for atmospheric irregularities in the horizontal, and applied a modern retrieval system to the simulated data. Our findings are as follows:

  • The fluctuations associated with internal gravity waves are apparent in the retrieved temperature profiles;
  • Even the fluctuations associated with horizontal wavelengths much shorter than the limb path of the occultation ray are clearly evident in retrieval, which is counter-intuitive for a limb-sounding measurement that should average over the limb path;
  • Relative phasing of the waves in the vertical over the RO soundings in one cluster is apparent, indicating the potential for tomography to obtain momentum fluxes;
  • A spectrum of waves is present in every sounding, making it nearly impossible to discern horizontal wavelengths by simple analytical approaches; and
  • There appears to be a misregistration of the waves in height, possibly due to a fault in fusing together the geometry of MPAS and the wave optics propagator.

The pathway forward is clear: we need to apply machine learning algorithms to infer gravity wave momentum fluxes from a gravity wave tomography constellation of RO satellites, and the algorithm must be trained on the output of a more reliable non-hydrostatic atmospheric model.
